data.title: Former Negro League star hired as pitching coach for Kalamazoo Growlers
data.meta_description: Pedro Sierra, who pitched for the Indianapolis Clowns and the Detroit Stars in the former Negro League, has been hired as the new pitching coach for the Kalamazoo Growlers, the club announced today.
data.text:
Pedro Sierra

Pedro Sierra pitched for the Detroit Stars in the former Negro League from 1955 to 1958.

KALAMAZOO, MI â€“ Pedro Sierra, who pitched for the Indianapolis Clowns and the Detroit Stars in the former Negro League, has been hired as the new pitching coach for the Kalamazoo Growlers, the club announced today.

Sierra, who is now 76, now also pitched in the farm system for the Minnesota Twins and Washington Senators.

He will join the Growlers for the second season in Kalamazoo and the Northwoods League, which plays elite college players.

Born in Havana, Cuba, Sierra signed his first baseball contract at age 16 with the Clowns. He played in Indianapolis in 1954 and then in Detroit from 1955-58.

Sierra was then drafted into the U.S. Army and became a top pitcher for the Fort Hood Tankers. In the 1961 season, he had a no-hitter and 1.75 ERA, and led the team to the Army championship.

After he left the Army, Sierra continued to play baseball, including stints with Minnesota Twins and Washington Senators farm teams and the Provincial League in Quebec.

In 1976, Sierra left baseball, enrolled in college and eventually got a job working with at-risk youths in Washington, D.C.

He has worked as a pitching coach since 2002, first with the Pennsylvania Roadwarriors, then with the LaNew Bears of the Chinese Professional Baseball League in Taiwan and the Sussex Skyhawks of the Can-Am League.
